member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeMemoryMappedFileHandle
member.summary: Provides a safe handle that represents a memory-mapped file for sequential access.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeMemoryMappedViewHandle
member.summary: Provides a safe handle that represents a view of a block of unmanaged memory for random access.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptHandle
member.summary: Provides a safe handle that can be used by Cryptography Next Generation (CNG) objects.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptHandle.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptHandle.ReleaseHandle
member.summary: Releases a handle used by a Cryptography Next Generation (CNG) object.
member.returns: true if the handle is released successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptHandle.ReleaseNativeHandle
member.summary: Releases a native handle used by a Cryptography Next Generation (CNG) object.
member.returns: true if the handle is released successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptKeyHandle
member.summary: Provides a safe handle that represents a key (NCRYPT_KEY_HANDLE).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptKeyHandle.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptProviderHandle
member.summary: Provides a safe handle that represents a key storage provider (NCRYPT_PROV_HANDLE).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptProviderHandle.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptSecretHandle
member.summary: Provides a safe handle that represents a secret agreement value (NCRYPT_SECRET_HANDLE).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeNCryptSecretHandle.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafePipeHandle
member.summary: Represents a wrapper class for a pipe handle.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafePipeHandle.#ctor(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: An object that represents the pre-existing handle to use.
true to reliably release the handle during the finalization phase; false to prevent reliable release (not recommended).

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.TraceLogRetentionOption
member.summary: Specifies the file structure that will be used for the log.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.TraceLogRetentionOption.SingleFileUnboundedSize
member.summary: One file with no maximum file size restriction.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.TraceLogRetentionOption.SingleFileBoundedSize
member.summary: One file with a maximum file size that is determined by the property.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.TraceLogRetentionOption.UnlimitedSequentialFiles
member.summary: An unlimited number of sequential files, each with a maximum file size that is determined by the property. There is no logical bound to the number or size of the files, but it is limited by the physical constraints imposed by the computer.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.TraceLogRetentionOption.LimitedSequentialFiles
member.summary: A finite number of sequential files, each with a maximum file size. When the property value is reached, writing starts in a new file with an incremented integer suffix.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.TraceLogRetentionOption.LimitedCircularFiles
member.summary: A finite number of sequential files, each with a maximum file size. When the property value is reached, writing starts in a new file with an incremented integer suffix. When the property value is reached, the first file is cleared and overwritten. Files are then incrementally overwritten in a circular manner.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventProvider.WriteEvent(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventDescriptor@,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Writes an event. The event data is specified as a block of memory.
member.returns: Is true if the event is written; otherwise, false. If false, call the method to determine the cause of the failure.
member.param: An instance of that identifies the event to write.

Size of the event data to which the parameter points. The maximum event data size is limited to 64 KB minus the size of the event headers. The event size is less if the session's buffer size is less and the session includes extended data items with the event.
Pointer to the event data to write.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventProvider.WriteEvent(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventDescriptor@,System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes an event. The event data is specified as an array of objects.
member.returns: Is true if the event is written; otherwise, false. If false, call the method to determine the cause of the failure.
member.param: An instance of that identifies the event to write.

An array of objects that contain the event data to write. The object must be in the order specified in the manifest. The array is limited to 32 objects, of which only eight may be strings. The maximum data size for the event is limited to 64 KB minus the size of the event headers. The event size is less if the session's buffer size is less and the session includes extended data items with the event.This parameter can be null.
member.exception: The parameter contains too many objects or strings.

Level of detail included in the event. If the provider uses a manifest to define the event, set this value to the same level defined in the manifest.
Bit mask that specifies the event category. If the provider uses a manifest to define the event, set this value to the same keyword mask defined in the manifest.
member.exception: If is null.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventProvider.WriteTransferEvent(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventDescriptor@,System.Guid,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Links events together when tracing events in an end-to-end scenario. The event data is specified as a block of memory.
member.returns: Is true if the event is written; otherwise, false. If false, call the method to determine the cause of the failure.
member.param: An instance of that identifies the event to write.
Activity identifier from the previous component. Use this parameter to link your component's events to the previous component's events.

Size of the event data to which the parameter points. The maximum event data size is limited to 64 KB minus the size of the event headers. The event size is less if the session's buffer size is less and the session includes extended data items with the event.
Pointer to the event data to write.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventProvider.WriteTransferEvent(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventDescriptor@,System.Guid,System.Object[])

Activity identifier from the previous component. Use this parameter to link your component's events to the previous component's events.

An array of objects that contain the event data to write. The data must be in the order specified in the manifest. The array is limited to 32 objects, of which only eight may be strings. The maximum data size for the event is limited to 64 KB minus the size of the event headers. The event size is less if the session's buffer size is less and the session includes extended data items with the event.
member.exception: If contains too many objects or strings.

member.summary: The write was successful.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventProvider.WriteEventErrorCode.NoFreeBuffers
member.summary: The session ran out of free buffers to write to. This can occur during high event rates because the disk subsystem is overloaded or the number of buffers is too small. Rather than blocking until more buffers become available, the event is dropped. Consider increasing the number and size of the buffers for the session, or reducing the number of events written or the size of the events.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.EventProvider.WriteEventErrorCode.EventTooBig
member.summary: The event is larger than the session buffer size; events cannot span buffers.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogIsolation
member.summary: Defines the default access permissions for the event log. The Application and System values indicate that the log shares the access control list (ACL) with the appropriate Windows log (the Application or System event logs) and share the Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) session with other logs of the same isolation. All channels with Custom isolation use a private ETW session.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogIsolation.Application
member.summary: The log shares the access control list with the Application event log and shares the ETW session with other logs that have Application isolation.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogIsolation.System
member.summary: The log shares the access control list with the System event log and shares the ETW session with other logs that have System isolation.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogIsolation.Custom
member.summary: The event log is a custom event log that uses its own private ETW session.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogLink

member.summary: Gets the localized name of the event log.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the localized name of the event log.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogLink.IsImported
member.summary: Gets a Boolean value that determines whether the event log is imported, rather than defined in the event provider. An imported event log is defined in a different provider.
member.returns: Returns true if the event log is imported by the event provider, and returns false if the event log is not imported by the event provider.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogLink.LogName
member.summary: Gets the non-localized name of the event log associated with this object.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the non-localized name of the event log associated with this object.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogMode
member.summary: Determines the behavior for the event log service handles an event log when the log reaches its maximum allowed size (when the event log is full).

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogMode.Circular
member.summary: New events continue to be stored when the log file is full. Each new incoming event replaces the oldest event in the log.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogMode.AutoBackup
member.summary: Archive the log when full, do not overwrite events. The log is automatically archived when necessary. No events are overwritten.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogMode.Retain
member.summary: Do not overwrite events. Clear the log manually rather than automatically.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying the target of the query. The target can be an active event log or a log file.
member.param: The name of the event log to query, or the path to the event log file to query.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery.#ctor(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying the target of the query and the event query. The target can be an active event log or a log file.
member.param: The name of the event log to query, or the path to the event log file to query.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.
The event query used to retrieve events that match the query conditions.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery.ReverseDirection
member.summary: Gets or sets the Boolean value that determines whether to read events from the newest event in an event log to the oldest event in the log.
member.returns: Returns true if events are read from the newest event in the log to the oldest event, and returns false if events are read from the oldest event in the log to the newest event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery.Session
member.summary: Gets or sets the session that access the Event Log service on the local computer or a remote computer. This object can be set to access a remote event log by creating a object or an object with this object.
member.returns: Returns an object.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery.TolerateQueryErrors
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that determines whether this query will continue to retrieve events when the query has an error.
member.returns: true indicates that the query will continue to retrieve events even if the query fails for some logs, and false indicates that this query will not continue to retrieve events when the query fails.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader
member.summary: Enables you to read events from an event log based on an event query. The events that are read by this object are returned as objects.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying an event query.
member.param: The event query used to retrieve events.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventBookmark)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying an event query and a bookmark that is used as starting position for the query.
member.param: The event query used to retrieve events.
The bookmark (placeholder) used as a starting position in the event log or stream of events. Only events logged after the bookmark event will be returned by the query.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying an active event log to retrieve events from.
member.param: The name of the event log to retrieve events from.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.#ctor(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying the name of an event log to retrieve events from or the path to a log file to retrieve events from.
member.param: The name of the event log to retrieve events from, or the path to the event log file to retrieve events from.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.BatchSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of events retrieved from the stream of events on every read operation.
member.returns: Returns an integer value.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.CancelReading
member.summary: Cancels the current query operation.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all the resources used by this object.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by this object, and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.LogStatus
member.summary: Gets the status of each event log or log file associated with the event query in this object.
member.returns: Returns a list of objects that each contain status information about an event log associated with the event query in this object.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.ReadEvent
member.summary: Reads the next event that is returned from the event query in this object.
member.returns: Returns an object.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.ReadEvent(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Reads the next event that is returned from the event query in this object.
member.returns: Returns an object.
member.param: The maximum time to allow the read operation to run before canceling the operation.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.Seek(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventBookmark)
member.summary: Changes the position in the event stream where the next event that is read will come from by specifying a bookmark event. No events logged before the bookmark event will be retrieved.
member.param: The bookmark (placeholder) used as a starting position in the event log or stream of events. Only events that have been logged after the bookmark event will be returned by the query.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.Seek(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventBookmark,System.Int64)
member.summary: Changes the position in the event stream where the next event that is read will come from by specifying a bookmark event and an offset number of events from the bookmark. No events logged before the bookmark plus the offset will be retrieved.
member.param: The bookmark (placeholder) used as a starting position in the event log or stream of events. Only events that have been logged after the bookmark event will be returned by the query.
The offset number of events to change the position of the bookmark.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReader.Seek(System.IO.SeekOrigin,System.Int64)
member.summary: Changes the position in the event stream where the next event that is read will come from by specifying a starting position and an offset from the starting position. No events logged before the starting position plus the offset will be retrieved.
member.param: A value from the enumeration defines where in the stream of events to start querying for events.
The offset number of events to add to the origin.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReadingException
member.summary: Represents an exception that is thrown when an error occurred while reading, querying, or subscribing to the events in an event log.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReadingException.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReadingException.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with serialized data.
member.param: The object that holds the serialized object data about the exception thrown.
The object that contains contextual information about the source or destination.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReadingException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying the error message that describes the current exception.
member.param: The error message that describes the current exception.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogReadingException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with an error message and inner exception.
member.param: The error message that describes the current exception.
The Exception instance that caused the current exception.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord
member.summary: Contains the properties of an event instance for an event that is received from an object. The event properties provide information about the event such as the name of the computer where the event was logged and the time that the event was created.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ActivityId
member.summary: Gets the globally unique identifier (GUID) for the activity in process for which the event is involved. This allows consumers to group related activities.
member.returns: Returns a GUID value.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Bookmark
member.summary: Gets a placeholder (bookmark) that corresponds to this event. This can be used as a placeholder in a stream of events.
member.returns: Returns a object.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ContainerLog
member.summary: Gets the name of the event log or the event log file in which the event is stored.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the name of the event log or the event log file in which the event is stored.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by this object, and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.FormatDescription
member.summary: Gets the event message in the current locale.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the event message in the current locale.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.FormatDescription(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Object})
member.summary: Gets the event message, replacing variables in the message with the specified values.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the event message in the current locale.
member.param: The values used to replace variables in the event message. Variables are represented by %n, where n is a number.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.GetPropertyValues(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogPropertySelector)
member.summary: Gets the enumeration of the values of the user-supplied event properties, or the results of XPath-based data if the event has XML representation.
member.returns: Returns a list of objects.
member.param: Selects the property values to return.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Id
member.summary: Gets the identifier for this event. All events with this identifier value represent the same type of event.
member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Keywords
member.summary: Gets the keyword mask of the event. Get the value of the property to get the name of the keywords used in this mask.
member.returns: Returns a long value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.KeywordsDisplayNames
member.summary: Gets the display names of the keywords used in the keyword mask for this event.
member.returns: Returns an enumerable collection of strings that contain the display names of the keywords used in the keyword mask for this event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Level
member.summary: Gets the level of the event. The level signifies the severity of the event. For the name of the level, get the value of the property.
member.returns: Returns a byte value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.LevelDisplayName
member.summary: Gets the display name of the level for this event.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the display name of the level for this event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.LogName
member.summary: Gets the name of the event log where this event is logged.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains a name of the event log that contains this event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.MachineName
member.summary: Gets the name of the computer on which this event was logged.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the name of the computer on which this event was logged.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.MatchedQueryIds
member.summary: Gets a list of query identifiers that this event matches. This event matches a query if the query would return this event.
member.returns: Returns an enumerable collection of integer values.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Opcode
member.summary: Gets the opcode of the event. The opcode defines a numeric value that identifies the activity or a point within an activity that the application was performing when it raised the event. For the name of the opcode, get the value of the property.
member.returns: Returns a short value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.OpcodeDisplayName
member.summary: Gets the display name of the opcode for this event.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the display name of the opcode for this event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ProcessId
member.summary: Gets the process identifier for the event provider that logged this event.
member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Properties
member.summary: Gets the user-supplied properties of the event.
member.returns: Returns a list of objects.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ProviderId
member.summary: Gets the globally unique identifier (GUID) of the event provider that published this event.
member.returns: Returns a GUID value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ProviderName
member.summary: Gets the name of the event provider that published this event.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the name of the event provider that published this event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Qualifiers
member.summary: Gets qualifier numbers that are used for event identification.
member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.RecordId
member.summary: Gets the event record identifier of the event in the log.
member.returns: Returns a long value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.RelatedActivityId
member.summary: Gets a globally unique identifier (GUID) for a related activity in a process for which an event is involved.
member.returns: Returns a GUID value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Task
member.summary: Gets a task identifier for a portion of an application or a component that publishes an event. A task is a 16-bit value with 16 top values reserved. This type allows any value between 0x0000 and 0xffef to be used. For the name of the task, get the value of the property.
member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.TaskDisplayName
member.summary: Gets the display name of the task for the event.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the display name of the task for the event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ThreadId
member.summary: Gets the thread identifier for the thread that the event provider is running in.
member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.TimeCreated
member.summary: Gets the time, in format, that the event was created.
member.returns: Returns a value. The value can be null.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.ToXml
member.summary: Gets the XML representation of the event. All of the event properties are represented in the event's XML. The XML conforms to the event schema.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the XML representation of the event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.UserId
member.summary: Gets the security descriptor of the user whose context is used to publish the event.
member.returns: Returns a value.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogRecord.Version
member.summary: Gets the version number for the event.
member.returns: Returns a byte value. This value can be null.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession
member.summary: Used to access the Event Log service on the local computer or a remote computer so you can manage and gather information about the event logs and event providers on the computer.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new object, establishes a connection with the local Event Log service.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new object, and establishes a connection with the Event Log service on the specified computer. The credentials (user name and password) of the user who calls the method is used for the credentials to access the remote computer.
member.param: The name of the computer on which to connect to the Event Log service.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Security.SecureString,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.SessionAuthentication)
member.summary: Initializes a new object, and establishes a connection with the Event Log service on the specified computer. The specified credentials (user name and password) are used for the credentials to access the remote computer.
member.param: The name of the computer on which to connect to the Event Log service.
The domain of the specified user.
The user name used to connect to the remote computer.
The password used to connect to the remote computer.
The type of connection to use for the connection to the remote computer.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.CancelCurrentOperations
member.summary: Cancels any operations (such as reading an event log or subscribing to an event log) that are currently active for the Event Log service that this session object is connected to.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.ClearLog(System.String)
member.summary: Clears events from the specified event log.
member.param: The name of the event log to clear all the events from.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.ClearLog(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Clears events from the specified event log, and saves the cleared events to the specified file.
member.param: The name of the event log to clear all the events from.
The path to the file in which the cleared events will be saved. The file should end in .evtx.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all the resources used by this object.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by this object, and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.ExportLog(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Exports events into an external log file. The events are stored without the event messages.
member.param: The name of the event log to export events from, or the path to the event log file to export events from.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.
The query used to select the events to export. Only the events returned from the query will be exported.
The path to the log file (ends in .evtx) in which the exported events will be stored after this method is executed.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.ExportLog(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Exports events into an external log file. A flag can be set to indicate that the method will continue exporting events even if the specified query fails for some logs. The events are stored without the event messages.
member.param: The name of the event log to export events from, or the path to the event log file to export events from.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.
The query used to select the events to export. Only the events returned from the query will be exported.
The path to the log file (ends in .evtx) in which the exported events will be stored after this method is executed.

true indicates that the method will continue exporting events even if the specified query fails for some logs, and false indicates that this method will not continue to export events when the specified query fails.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.ExportLogAndMessages(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Exports events and their messages into an external log file.
member.param: The name of the event log to export events from, or the path to the event log file to export events from.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.
The query used to select the events to export. Only the events returned from the query will be exported.
The path to the log file (ends in .evtx) in which the exported events will be stored after this method is executed.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.ExportLogAndMessages(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Exports events and their messages into an external log file. A flag can be set to indicate that the method will continue exporting events even if the specified query fails for some logs. The event messages are exported in the specified language.
member.param: The name of the event log to export events from, or the path to the event log file to export events from.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.
The query used to select the events to export. Only the events returned from the query will be exported.
The path to the log file (ends in .evtx) in which the exported events will be stored after this method is executed.

true indicates that the method will continue exporting events even if the specified query fails for some logs, and false indicates that this method will not continue to export events when the specified query fails.
The culture that specifies which language that the exported event messages will be in.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.GetLogInformation(System.String,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.PathType)
member.summary: Gets an object that contains runtime information for the specified event log.
member.returns: Returns an object that contains information about the specified log.
member.param: The name of the event log to get information about, or the path to the event log file to get information about.
Specifies whether the string used in the path parameter specifies the name of an event log, or the path to an event log file.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.GetLogNames
member.summary: Gets an enumerable collection of all the event log names that are registered with the Event Log service.
member.returns: Returns an enumerable collection of strings that contain the event log names.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.GetProviderNames
member.summary: Gets an enumerable collection of all the event provider names that are registered with the Event Log service. An event provider is an application that publishes events to an event log.
member.returns: Returns an enumerable collection of strings that contain the event provider names.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogSession.GlobalSession
member.summary: Gets a static predefined session object that is connected to the Event Log service on the local computer.
member.returns: Returns an object that is a predefined session object that is connected to the Event Log service on the local computer.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogStatus
member.summary: Contains the status code or error code for a specific event log. This status can be used to determine if the event log is available for an operation.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogStatus.LogName
member.summary: Gets the name of the event log for which the status code is obtained.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the name of the event log for which the status code is obtained.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogStatus.StatusCode
member.summary: Gets the status code or error code for the event log. This status or error is the result of a read or subscription operation on the event log.
member.returns: Returns an integer value.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogType
member.summary: Defines the type of events that are logged in an event log. Each log can only contain one type of event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogType.Administrative
member.summary: These events are primarily for end users, administrators, and support. The events that are found in the Administrative type logs indicate a problem and a well-defined solution that an administrator can act on. An example of an administrative event is an event that occurs when an application fails to connect to a printer.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogType.Operational
member.summary: Events in an operational type event log are used for analyzing and diagnosing a problem or occurrence. They can be used to trigger tools or tasks based on the problem or occurrence. An example of an operational event is an event that occurs when a printer is added or removed from a system.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogType.Analytical
member.summary: Events in an analytic event log are published in high volume. They describe program operation and indicate problems that cannot be handled by user intervention.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogType.Debug
member.summary: Events in a debug type event log are used solely by developers to diagnose a problem for debugging.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher
member.summary: Allows you to subscribe to incoming events. Each time a desired event is published to an event log, the event is raised, and the method that handles this event will be executed.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying an event query.
member.param: Specifies a query for the event subscription. When an event is logged that matches the criteria expressed in the query, then the event is raised.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventBookmark)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying an event query and a bookmark that is used as starting position for the query.
member.param: Specifies a query for the event subscription. When an event is logged that matches the criteria expressed in the query, then the event is raised.
The bookmark (placeholder) used as a starting position in the event log or stream of events. Only events that have been logged after the bookmark event will be returned by the query.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.#ctor(System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogQuery,System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventBookmark,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying an event query, a bookmark that is used as starting position for the query, and a Boolean value that determines whether to read the events that already exist in the event log.
member.param: Specifies a query for the event subscription. When an event is logged that matches the criteria expressed in the query, then the event is raised.
The bookmark (placeholder) used as a starting position in the event log or stream of events. Only events that have been logged after the bookmark event will be returned by the query.

A Boolean value that determines whether to read the events that already exist in the event log. If this value is true, then the existing events are read and if this value is false, then the existing events are not read.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by specifying the name or path to an event log.
member.param: The path or name of the event log monitor for events. If any event is logged in this event log, then the event is raised.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all the resources used by this object.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the unmanaged resources used by this object, and optionally releases the managed resources.
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.Enabled
member.summary: Determines whether this object starts delivering events to the event delegate.
member.returns: Returns true when this object can deliver events to the event delegate, and returns false when this object has stopped delivery.

member.name: E:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventLogWatcher.EventRecordWritten
member.summary: Allows setting a delegate (event handler method) that gets called every time an event is published that matches the criteria specified in the event query for this object.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventMetadata
member.summary: Contains the metadata (properties and settings) for an event that is defined in an event provider.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventMetadata.Description
member.summary: Gets the description template associated with the event using the current thread locale for the description language.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the description template associated with the event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventMetadata.Id
member.summary: Gets the identifier of the event that is defined in the event provider.
member.returns: Returns a long value that is the event identifier.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventMetadata.Keywords
member.summary: Gets the keywords associated with the event that is defined in the even provider.
member.returns: Returns an enumerable collection of objects.

member.summary: Gets the opcode associated with this event that is defined by an event provider. The opcode defines a numeric value that identifies the activity or a point within an activity that the application was performing when it raised the event.

member.summary: Gets the template string for the event. Templates are used to describe data that is used by a provider when an event is published. Templates optionally specify XML that provides the structure of an event. The XML allows values that the event publisher provides to be inserted during the rendering of an event.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the template for the event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventMetadata.Version
member.summary: Gets the version of the event that qualifies the event identifier.
member.returns: Returns a byte value.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord
member.summary: Defines the properties of an event instance for an event that is received from an object. The event properties provide information about the event such as the name of the computer where the event was logged and the time the event was created. This class is an abstract class. The class implements this class.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.returns: Returns a GUID value.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord.Bookmark
member.summary: Gets a placeholder (bookmark) that corresponds to this event. This can be used as a placeholder in a stream of events.

member.returns: Returns an enumerable collection of strings that contain the display names of the keywords used in the keyword mask for this event.

member.returns: Returns a byte value. This value can be null.

member.summary: Gets the name of the computer on which this event was logged.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the name of the computer on which this event was logged.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord.Opcode
member.summary: Gets the opcode of the event. The opcode defines a numeric value that identifies the activity or a point within an activity that the application was performing when it raised the event. For the name of the opcode, get the value of the property.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord.Task
member.summary: Gets a task identifier for a portion of an application or a component that publishes an event. A task is a 16-bit value with 16 top values reserved. This type allows any value between 0x0000 and 0xffef to be used. To obtain the task name, get the value of the property.
member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.summary: Gets the display name of the task for the event.

member.returns: Returns an integer value. This value can be null.

member.summary: Gets the time, in format, that the event was created.
member.returns: Returns a value. The value can be null.

member.summary: Gets the XML representation of the event. All of the event properties are represented in the event XML. The XML conforms to the event schema.
member.returns: Returns a string that contains the XML representation of the event.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord.UserId

member.returns: Returns a value.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.EventRecord.Version
member.summary: Gets the version number for the event.
member.returns: Returns a byte value. This value can be null.

member.summary: When the event is raised, an instance of this object is passed to the delegate method that handles the event. This object contains the event that was published to the event log or the exception that occurred when the event subscription failed.

member.summary: Gets the event record that is published to the event log. This event matches the criteria from the query specified in the event subscription.
member.returns: Returns a object.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.SessionAuthentication
member.summary: Defines values for the type of authentication used during a Remote Procedure Call (RPC) login to a server. This login occurs when you create a object that specifies a connection to a remote computer.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.SessionAuthentication.Default
member.summary: Use the default authentication method during RPC login. The default authentication is equivalent to Negotiate.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.SessionAuthentication.Negotiate
member.summary: Use the Negotiate authentication method during RPC login. This allows the client application to select the most appropriate authentication method (NTLM or Kerberos) for the situation.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.SessionAuthentication.Kerberos
member.summary: Use Kerberos authentication during RPC login.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.SessionAuthentication.Ntlm
member.summary: Use Windows NT LAN Manager (NTLM) authentication during RPC login.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords
member.summary: Defines the standard keywords that are attached to events by the event provider. For more information about keywords, see .

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.None
member.summary: This value indicates that no filtering on keyword is performed when the event is published.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.WdiContext
member.summary: Attached to all Windows Diagnostic Infrastructure (WDI) context events.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.WdiDiagnostic
member.summary: Attached to all Windows Diagnostic Infrastructure (WDI) diagnostic events.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.Sqm
member.summary: Attached to all Service Quality Mechanism (SQM) events.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.AuditFailure
member.summary: Attached to all failed security audit events. This keyword should only be used for events in the Security log.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.AuditSuccess
member.summary: Attached to all successful security audit events. This keyword should only be used for events in the Security log.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.CorrelationHint
member.summary: Attached to transfer events where the related Activity ID (Correlation ID) is a computed value and is not guaranteed to be unique (not a real GUID).

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventKeywords.EventLogClassic
member.summary: Attached to events which are raised using the RaiseEvent function.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel
member.summary: Defines the standard event levels that are used in the Event Log service. The level defines the severity of the event. Custom event levels can be defined beyond these standard levels. For more information about levels, see .

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel.LogAlways
member.summary: This value indicates that not filtering on the level is done during the event publishing.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel.Critical
member.summary: This level corresponds to critical errors, which is a serious error that has caused a major failure.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel.Error
member.summary: This level corresponds to normal errors that signify a problem.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel.Warning
member.summary: This level corresponds to warning events. For example, an event that gets published because a disk is nearing full capacity is a warning event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel.Informational
member.summary: This level corresponds to informational events or messages that are not errors. These events can help trace the progress or state of an application.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventLevel.Verbose
member.summary: This level corresponds to lengthy events or messages.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode
member.summary: Defines the standard opcodes that are attached to events by the event provider. For more information about opcodes, see .

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Info
member.summary: An event with this opcode is an informational event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Start
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published when an application starts a new transaction or activity. This can be embedded into another transaction or activity when multiple events with the Start opcode follow each other without an event with a Stop opcode.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Stop
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published when an activity or a transaction in an application ends. The event corresponds to the last unpaired event with a Start opcode.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.DataCollectionStart
member.summary: An event with this opcode is a trace collection start event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.DataCollectionStop
member.summary: An event with this opcode is a trace collection stop event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Extension
member.summary: An event with this opcode is an extension event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Reply
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published after an activity in an application replies to an event.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Resume
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published after an activity in an application resumes from a suspended state. The event should follow an event with the Suspend opcode.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Suspend
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published when an activity in an application is suspended.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Send
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published when one activity in an application transfers data or system resources to another activity.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventOpcode.Receive
member.summary: An event with this opcode is published when one activity in an application receives data.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventTask
member.summary: Defines the standard tasks that are attached to events by the event provider. For more information about tasks, see .

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.Eventing.Reader.StandardEventTask.None
member.summary: No task is used to identify a portion of an application that publishes an event.

Guid that uniquely identifies the counter set for a provider. Use the Guid specified in the manifest.
Identifies the type of the counter set, for example, whether the counter set is a single or multiple instance counter set.
member.exception: Not enough memory is available to complete the operation.
Not supported prior to Windows Vista.
One of the parameters is NULL or not valid.
An underlying Win32 function call failed.

member.param: Identifies the counter. Use the same value that you used in the manifest to define the counter.
Identifies the counter type. The counter type determines how the counter data is calculated, averaged, and displayed.
member.exception: The counter identifier already exists in the set or is negative, or the counter type is NULL or not valid.
You cannot add counters to the counter set after creating an instance of the counter set.

Name of the counter. You can use this name to index the counter in the counter set instance. (See .)
member.exception: The counter identifier already exists in the set or is negative, or the counter type is NULL or not valid.
You cannot add counters to the counter set after creating an instance of the counter set.

member.summary: The counter set contains single instance counters, for example, a counter that measures physical memory.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.Multiple
member.summary: The counter set contains multiple instance counters, for example, a counter that measures the average disk I/O for a process.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.GlobalAggregate
member.summary: The counter set contains single instance counters whose aggregate value is obtained from one or more sources. For example, a counter in this type of counter set might obtain the number of reads from each of the three hard disks on the computer and sum their values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.GlobalAggregateWithHistory
member.summary: This type is similar to except that this counter set type stores all counter values for the lifetime of the consumer application (the counter value is cached beyond the lifetime of the counter). For example, if one of the hard disks in the global aggregate example were to become unavailable, the total bytes read by that disk would still be available and used to calculate the aggregate value.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.MultipleAggregate
member.summary: The counter set contains multiple instance counters whose aggregate value is obtained from all instances of the counter. For example, a counter in this type of counter set might obtain the total thread execution time for all threads in a multithreaded application and sum their values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.InstanceAggregate
member.summary: This type is similar to , except that instead of aggregating all instance data to one aggregated (_Total) instance, it will aggregate counter data from instances of the same name. For example, if multiple provider processes contained instances named IExplore, and CounterSet will show multiple IExplore instances (IExplore, IExplore#1, IExplore#2, and so on); however, a instance type will publish only one IExplore instance with aggregated counter data from all instances named IExplore.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType
member.summary: Defines the possible types of counters. Each counter is assigned a counter type. The counter type determines how the counter data is calculated, averaged, and displayed.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.QueueLength
member.summary: This counter type is designed to monitor the average length of a queue to a resource over time. It shows the difference between the queue lengths observed during the last two sample intervals divided by the duration of the interval. (See the PERF_COUNTER_QUEUELEN_TYPE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.LargeQueueLength
member.summary: This counter type monitors the average length of a queue to a resource over time. Counters of this type display the difference between the queue lengths observed during the last two sample intervals, divided by the duration of the interval. This counter type is the same as the counter type, except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. (See the PERF_COUNTER_LARGE_QUEUELEN_TYPE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.QueueLength100Ns
member.summary: This counter type measures the queue-length space-time product using a 100-nanosecond time base. (See the PERF_COUNTER_100NS_QUEUELEN_TYPE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.QueueLengthObjectTime
member.summary: This counter type measures the queue-length space-time product using an object-specific time base. (See the PERF_COUNTER_OBJ_QUEUELEN_TYPE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawData32
member.summary: This counter type shows the last observed value only. It does not display an average. (See the PERF_COUNTER_RAWCOUNT counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawData64
member.summary: This counter type shows the last observed value only, not an average. It is the same as the counter type, except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. (See the PERF_COUNTER_LARGE_RAWCOUNT counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawDataHex32
member.summary: This counter type shows the most recently observed value, in hexadecimal format. It does not display an average. (See the PERF_COUNTER_RAWCOUNT_HEX counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawDataHex64
member.summary: This counter type shows the last observed value, in hexadecimal format. It is the same as the counter type, except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. (See the PERF_COUNTER_LARGE_RAWCOUNT_HEX counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RateOfCountPerSecond32
member.summary: This counter type shows the average number of operations completed during each second of the sample interval. Counters of this type measure time in ticks of the system clock. (See the PERF_COUNTER_COUNTER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RateOfCountPerSecond64
member.summary: This counter type shows the average number of operations completed during each second of the sample interval. Counters of this type measure time in ticks of the system clock. This counter type is the same as the type, but it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. (See the PERF_COUNTER_BULK_COUNT counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawFraction32
member.summary: This counter type shows the ratio of a subset to its set as a percentage. For example, it compares the number of bytes in use on a disk to the total number of bytes on the disk. Counters of this type display the current percentage only, not an average over time. (See the PERF_RAW_FRACTION counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawFraction64
member.summary: This counter type shows the ratio of a subset to its set as a percentage. For example, it compares the number of bytes in use on a disk to the total number of bytes on the disk. Counters of this type display the current percentage only, not an average over time. It is the same as the counter type, except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawBase32
member.summary: This counter type collects the last observed value only. The value is used as the denominator of a counter that presents a general arithmetic fraction. This type supports the counter type. (See the PERF_RAW_BASE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.RawBase64
member.summary: This counter type collects the last observed value. It is the same as the counter type except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. This type supports the counter type. (See the PERF_LARGE_RAW_BASE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.SampleFraction
member.summary: This counter type shows the average ratio of hits to all operations during the last two sample intervals. (See the PERF_SAMPLE_FRACTION counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.SampleCounter
member.summary: This counter type shows the average number of operations completed in one second. It measures time in units of ticks of the system performance timer. The variable F represents the number of ticks that occur in one second. The value of F is factored into the equation so that the result is displayed in seconds. (See the PERF_SAMPLE_COUNTER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.SampleBase
member.summary: This counter stores the number of sampling interrupts taken and is used as a denominator in the sampling fraction. This type supports the counter type.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.AverageTimer32
member.summary: This counter type measures the average time it takes to complete a process or operation. Counters of this type display a ratio of the total elapsed time of the sample interval to the number of processes or operations completed during that time. This counter type measures time in ticks of the system clock. (See the PERF_AVERAGE_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.AverageBase
member.summary: This counter is used as the base data (denominator) in the computation of time or count averages for the and counter types. This counter type collects the last observed value only. (See the PERF_AVERAGE_BASE counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.AverageCount64
member.summary: This counter type shows how many items are processed, on average, during an operation. Counters of this type display a ratio of the items processed (such as bytes sent) to the number of operations completed. The ratio is calculated by comparing the number of items processed during the last interval to the number of operations completed during the last interval. (See the PERF_AVERAGE_BULK counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PercentageActive
member.summary: This counter type shows the average time that a component was active as a percentage of the total sample time. (See the PERF_COUNTER_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PercentageNotActive
member.summary: This is an inverse counter type. Inverse counters measure the time that a component is not active and derive the active time from that measurement. Counters of this type display the average percentage of active time observed during sample interval. The value of these counters is calculated by monitoring the percentage of time that the service was inactive and then subtracting that value from 100 percent. This counter type is the same as the counter type, except that it measures time in units of ticks of the system performance timer, rather than in 100 nanosecond units. (See the PERF_COUNTER_TIMER_INV counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PercentageActive100Ns
member.summary: This counter type shows the active time of a component as a percentage of the total elapsed time of the sample interval. It measures time in units of 100 nanoseconds. Counters of this type are designed to measure the activity of one component at a time. (See the PERF_100NSEC_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PercentageNotActive100Ns
member.summary: This counter type shows the average percentage of active time observed during the sample interval. This is an inverse counter. Inverse counters are calculated by monitoring the percentage of time that the service was inactive and then subtracting that value from 100 percent. (See the PERF_100NSEC_TIMER_INV counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.ElapsedTime
member.summary: This counter type shows the total time between when the component or process started and the time when this value is calculated. (See the PERF_ELAPSED_TIME counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.MultiTimerPercentageActive
member.summary: This counter type is a multitimer. Multitimers collect data from more than one instance of a component, such as a processor or disk. Counters of this type display the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. Because the numerator records the active time of components operating simultaneously, the resulting percentage can exceed 100 percent. This counter type differs from in that it measures time in units of ticks of the system performance timer, rather than in 100 nanosecond units. (See the PERF_COUNTER_MULTI_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.MultiTimerPercentageNotActive
member.summary: This counter type shows the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. This counter type is an inverse multitimer. Multitimers monitor more than one instance of a component, such as a processor or disk. Inverse counters measure the time that a component is not active and derive the active time from that measurement. This counter differs from in that it measures time in units of ticks of the system performance timer, rather than in 100 nanosecond units. (See the PERF_COUNTER_MULTI_TIMER_INV counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.MultiTimerPercentageActive100Ns
member.summary: This counter type shows the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. It measures time in 100 nanosecond units. This counter type is a multitimer. Multitimers are designed to monitor more than one instance of a component, such as a processor or disk. (See the PERF_100NSEC_MULTI_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.MultiTimerPercentageNotActive100Ns
member.summary: This counter type shows the active time of one or more components as a percentage of the total time of the sample interval. Counters of this type measure time in 100 nanosecond units. This counter type is an inverse multitimer. Multitimers are designed to monitor more than one instance of a component, such as a processor or disk. Inverse counters measure the time that a component is not active and derive its active time from the measurement of inactive time. (See the PERF_100NSEC_MULTI_TIMER_INV counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.MultiTimerBase
member.summary: Indicates the number of items sampled. It is used as the denominator in the calculations to get an average among the items sampled when taking timings of multiple, but similar, items. This type supports the following counter types: , , , and .

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.Delta32
member.summary: This counter type shows the change in the measured attribute between the two most recent sample intervals. (See the PERF_COUNTER_DELTA counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.Delta64
member.summary: This counter type shows the change in the measured attribute between the two most recent sample intervals. It is the same as the counter type, except that it uses larger fields to accommodate larger values. (See the PERF_COUNTER_LARGE_DELTA counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.ObjectSpecificTimer
member.summary: This 64-bit counter type is a timer that displays in object-specific units. (See the PERF_OBJ_TIME_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PrecisionSystemTimer
member.summary: This counter type shows a value that consists of two counter values: the count of the elapsed time of the event being monitored, and the frequency from the system performance timer. This counter type differs from other counter timers in that the clock tick value accompanies the counter value, eliminating any possible difference due to latency from the function call. Precision counter types are used when standard system timers are not precise enough for accurate readings. (See the PERF_PRECISION_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PrecisionTimer100Ns
member.summary: This counter type shows a value that consists of two counter values: the count of the elapsed time of the event being monitored, and the "clock" time from a private timer in the same units. It measures time in 100 nanosecond units. This counter type differs from other counter timers in that the clock tick value accompanies the counter value eliminating any possible difference due to latency from the function call. Precision counter types are used when standard system timers are not precise enough for accurate readings. (See the PERF_PRECISION_100NS_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType.PrecisionObjectSpecificTimer
member.summary: This counter type shows a value that consists of two counter values: the count of the elapsed time of the event being monitored, and the frequency specified in the PerfFreq field of the object header. This counter type differs from other counter timers in that the clock tick value accompanies the counter value so as to eliminate any possible difference due to latency from the function call. Precision counter types are used when standard system timers are not precise enough for accurate readings. (See the PERF_PRECISION_OBJECT_TIMER counter type in the deployment kit.)

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryBinaryOperation(System.Dynamic.BinaryOperationBinder,System.Object,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides implementation for binary operations. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as addition and multiplication.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)
member.param: Provides information about the binary operation. The binder.Operation property returns an object. For example, for the sum = first + second statement, where first and second are derived from the DynamicObject class, binder.Operation returns ExpressionType.Add.
The right operand for the binary operation. For example, for the sum = first + second statement, where first and second are derived from the DynamicObject class, is equal to second.
The result of the binary operation.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryConvert(System.Dynamic.ConvertBinder,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides implementation for type conversion operations. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations that convert an object from one type to another.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)
member.param: Provides information about the conversion operation. The binder.Type property provides the type to which the object must be converted. For example, for the statement (String)sampleObject in C# (CType(sampleObject, Type) in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Type returns the type. The binder.Explicit property provides information about the kind of conversion that occurs. It returns true for explicit conversion and false for implicit conversion.
The result of the type conversion operation.

member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a language-specific run-time exception is thrown.)
member.param: Provides information about the initialization operation.
The arguments that are passed to the object during initialization. For example, for the new SampleType(100) operation, where SampleType is the type derived from the class, is equal to 100.
The result of the initialization.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryGetMember(System.Dynamic.GetMemberBinder,System.Object@)
member.summary: Provides the implementation for operations that get member values. Classes derived from the class can override this method to specify dynamic behavior for operations such as getting a value for a property.
member.returns: true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false. If this method returns false, the run-time binder of the language determines the behavior. (In most cases, a run-time exception is thrown.)
member.param: Provides information about the object that called the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member on which the dynamic operation is performed. For example, for the Console.WriteLine(sampleObject.SampleProperty) statement, where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleProperty". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.
The result of the get operation. For example, if the method is called for a property, you can assign the property value to .

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryInvoke(System.Dynamic.InvokeBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)

member.param: Provides information about the invoke operation.
The arguments that are passed to the object during the invoke operation. For example, for the sampleObject(100) operation, where sampleObject is derived from the class, is equal to 100.
The result of the object invocation.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TryInvokeMember(System.Dynamic.InvokeMemberBinder,System.Object[],System.Object@)

member.param: Provides information about the dynamic operation. The binder.Name property provides the name of the member on which the dynamic operation is performed. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleMethod(100), where sampleObject is an instance of the class derived from the class, binder.Name returns "SampleMethod". The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.

The arguments that are passed to the object member during the invoke operation. For example, for the statement sampleObject.SampleMethod(100), where sampleObject is derived from the class, is equal to 100.
The result of the member invocation.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.DynamicObject.TrySetIndex(System.Dynamic.SetIndexBinder,System.Object[],System.Object)

The indexes that are used in the operation. For example, for the sampleObject[3] = 10 operation in C# (sampleObject(3) = 10 in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is derived from the class, is equal to 3.

The value to set to the object that has the specified index. For example, for the sampleObject[3] = 10 operation in C# (sampleObject(3) = 10 in Visual Basic), where sampleObject is derived from the class, is equal to 10.

The binder.IgnoreCase property specifies whether the member name is case-sensitive.

member.summary: Read and write access to the file that can can store and run executable code.
